Violet Evergarden -Despite what the metal arms of the protagonist may have you believe- is not an action-focused show. So if that's what you're looking for then you've already been warned. It's also likely a reason why previous reviews have commented on the slow nature of the first few episodes; expecting action. Rather- it's a story that uses the background of war and conflict to enrich it's main character's conflict and take the viewer on a journey of self-discovery and tears and is definitely worth watching past the first 5 episodes. When I started off watching this show I wasn't expecting to be overwhelmed bycreative subplots that brought me to tears nearly every episode. But I was pleasantly surprised. Overall, I rate this anime a 9/10. Reasons are below:(WARNING: MILD SPOILERS AHEAD)


Story(broken up into 3 different aspects of it)- 8/10

Setting: It isn't too hard to believe- it's a post-war society in a place that resembles Eastern Europe. The setting remains consistent throughout the series which makes the world more believable and immersive. They also portray the many places the main Character (Violet Evergarden) beautifully in a way that doesn't distract the viewer from the actual story or characters. There are a couple of things that bother me though- including the fact that they somehow have a perfect control over making metal replacements for entire limbs like in FMA, but have just recently discovered typewriters. A more basic grievance I have is that they never really establish the names of the places they visit- which makes it seem as if the story is all taking place in one big country (Which it isn't) 


Pacing: Like I said in the introductory paragraph, the story starts off almost excruciatingly slow- with small bits of action thrown in to keep the viewer entertained. While it does a good job establishing the main characters in the story that we'll be spending the rest of the show with, the lack of conflict and plot other than that dealing with Violet makes it slower than it has to be. After the first few episodes though, these issues are mostly resolved as the story moves to focus more on Violet's journey of self-discovery and forgiveness. This makes it easier for the plot to move on as the writers no longer need to arduously work to define characters that by themselves have little significance to the overall story.


Story Quality: As much as I enjoyed the overall story, I think the writers were a bit confused when they wrote this. The show starts off by defining the surrounding characters and follows a very linear journey of Violet as she learns to integrate herself into society from war, but immediately after she does so, it moves to a show about her journeying around and the adventures she goes on in those travels. The sudden shift makes it kind of confusing, but the transition isn't TOO abrupt and is a lot easier to follow than other terrible examples of writer indecision I've seen before. The story is nothing if not original and it IS original. 


Art 10/10: The art is absolutely phenomenal. As an aspiring artist myself, I couldn't tear my eyes from the beautiful animation and art that this anime features. Although it suffers from the typical problems like awkward facial expressions in large shots and chibi like expressions when it wants to seem comical, it more than makes up for it with moments that look like they were pulled straight out of an art museum in terms of color palette and beauty. 


Sound 8/10: The music is sometimes very reminiscent of BBC's Sherlock soundtrack, which is definitely a good thing. Though not as memorable, it does its job of complimenting the story as it goes along.


Character: The show does a pretty good job of defining its characters early on, but it suffers from an issue that I've seen in far too many shows; after it's finished giving backstory to it's sided characters, they become almost insignificant the story and makes the viewer feel almost as if they wasted the first few episodes on learning about characters that they never see again. Other than that though, the progression and development of the story's protagonist- Violet Evergarden- is done beautifully and makes the story addicting to keep up with.


Enjoyment: I shed tears of both happiness and sadness throughout this anime, I get the feeling that you will too. The art, soundtrack, and story all add up to make a beautifully comprehensive story of self-discovery that will likely not be forgotten for a very long time.

Disclaimer:
This is my second review. The reason I decided to write this is that no review seemed to do justice to this masterpiece. All of the spoilers I write come from episode 1. If you want to skip those, skip to the second part of the story chapter. 
Genre:
Melodrama (the kind where you know from the start thay you will cry a lot like in Anohana) 
Story (10/10):
Violet Evergarden tells a story of a 14 year old girl who grew up in the army, and lost her commander in the final battle of the war. However, no one can bear to tell her the truthabout her commander, so she tries to find out the meaning of his last words "I love you, Violet." To do this, she starts working as a letter writer trying to convey people's feelings. This is a very unique story that deserves an 8/10 in my opinion. 


Spoilers over


Where this show really shines though, are it's side stories that start at episode 3 if my memory serves me correctly. Almost every episode portrays the life of people in the aftermath of the war. A lot of them concern people who have lost someone they love, and the scars that has left in their hearts in a very humane way. They show the beauty of life, of love, and how letters made them see the light at the end of the tunnel. Each of these stories are so touching they deserve a 10/10.

The main story progresses slowly but steadily, and every episode revolves around Violet's clients, making Violet Evergarden a very episodic series, so don't expect cliffhangers here. 


Setting:

The show is set on a romanticised victorian era world where a large scale war has just ended. The world diverges only little from our world. Their alphabet and history are different, but that doesn't deter from the story. However our main character has more advanced arm protheses than what we have today similar to Fullmetal Alchemist. I didn't mind that though since I love the fantasy genre. 


Characters (9/10):

Having grown up in the army, Violet is an emotionally lacking girl who lost her arms in the war. She is exact and strict with herself and slowly learns to understand emotions. Having grown up in the army, she excels at everything that requires precision or diligence. It is difficult to connect with her at first, but she is slowly developed and her backstory revealed. (9/10)

In the company that Violet works at there are about four other letter writers that don't get much air time apart from one of them. They mainly serve as comparison to what successful letter writers are like in contrast to Violet. (6/10)

Here too the strong points of this show are the episodic side characters with so beautiful and sad backgrounds they have made me cry a couple of times. The people's grudges and regrets however get resolved in a way that has left me speechless time and time again through the letters that our heroine writes. Each episode after the first couple are built in a way that slowly reveals the side characters' history and the letters always tie the episode well together. (10/10)


Art (10/10):

I have never seen such outstanding art in an anime. Not even in Your name. The expressions are detailed, the backround sharp, and the animations fluid. The art does not try to express people listening on conversations with 5x bigger ears or the like but stays consistent as is expected of the genre. There was one episode in particular that left me in awe of the impressive animation (episode 6 or 7).


Sound (8/10):

The voice acting is great and the feelings come across, but I'm not very good at appraising it. At least I haven't heard any part with bad voice acting...  The ending is also, how do I put it... unique. There is also some background music, but I rarely pay attention to those so I am not appraising them.


Enjoyment and overall (10/10):

As most of the show has already been resolved, I can confidently say that Violet Evergarden is a masterpiece and the best anime of the season. It also topped my previous favourite Your name. The main story progresses slowly revolving around side stories each one more beautiful than the last, until it hits you with a few main story episodes that really touch your kokoro. The structure of the show is so different that it may be hard to get into at first, but the main attraction for the first ~7 episodes are the side stories. I would recommend this show to anyone who likes the drama genre like Anohana and Your name, or who is searching for very realistic and humane depictions of people like in Breaking Bad. Also, if you are searching for something Victorian after watching Gosick, this is the show. Don't watch if you hate the idea of a slow paced main story or are in search of action (this is drama.)

First and foremost, this is a beautiful show if nothing else. But by God, there definitely is substance behind the scenery too. The confusion people seem to be having with this show is that they think it's about a cute girl who's also a kick-ass soldier and does some wicked fighting. This, it most certainly is not. What this show is, however, is the tale of a young girl searching for meaning in a post-war world where she doesn't belong, while simultaneously trying to cope with her past actions. Violet Evergarden is a masterpiece of character development, storytelling, and the emotional payoff (on top ofKyoto Animations' brilliants executed world) that will have you tearing up after episode 3.

So I've seen a lot of reviews, and I decided to write my own after seeing EP.7.
At the beginning, I was enjoying the backstory that was teased piece by piece, really loving the art (best graphics I've ever seen in anime by far) and I was looking forward to see how the characters (especially Violet obviously) were going to be developed. 
In the first 4 episodes, they really took their time, and even if that didn't disturb me, it wasn't the case for everyone, which is totally understandable. 
In EP.5, the story was getting a little faster-paced, and that wasn't unpleasant at all, with agreat teasing in addition at the very end. 

Then dropped EP.6, which felt like a half-filler, because we were starting to see more development in Violet's character.


And this week arrived EP.7, and oh boy the little things I could criticize disappeared in a second. Without spoilers, Violet's character just went form half-blank to deeper than most shonen characters, and the story made a true leap forward: they finally concealed good graphics with a beautiful and well written story which almost made me drop a tear or two, even if we're just halfway there until the end of season 1. 


A bunch of people who watched it during airing were saying it was really cool, but had flaws that they hoped to see corrected in the next episodes. The big thing was to see if they would do it greatly or not, and they actually did it very well.


My rating, considering the 7th episode events, would be:

Story: 9, I don't give a 10 because it started a bit slowly and we need more backstory exposure.

Art : 10, just beautiful, would put 11 if I could.

Sound : 9, the OP and ED are cool, the OST fits nicely the scenes, I don't give a 10 because there aren't any outstanding tracks that I would listen to out of the show.

Character : 10, with secondary characters as good a Luculia and such development in Violet's one, I can't give less than 10.

Enjoyment : 10 Obviously, with these graphics and the story progressing in such a good way.

Overall : 10!


Now, I can't say much more without putting severe spoilers, so I'm just gonna say this:

Give this show a try, it deserves it. Definitely. Sit back, get your eyes ready, and enjoy :)

Initial Impressions:
Full disclosure, I didn't totally choose to watch this anime. Long story short, I offered to do a panel on it for the anime club I'm apart of... except at the time I hadn't seen the show. I'm honestly glad I showed up late because I feel I was able to look at this show critically rather than being filled to the brim with hype. Even though it may sound cheesy to give this show a perfect 10, I feel it really earned that perfect 10 from me. I enjoyed the beautiful set pieces, the emotional grounded struggles of Violet, and how each episodetold a story the contributed to the greater plot. I feel like 13 episodes were enough to me. It was satisfying in a way that I don't feel like I'm hanging from the mouth waiting for a sequel. So, let's get into the meat of it, shall we?


Story: 10/10

The story keeps itself grounded. A very vague synopsis is a child soldier (Violet) comes home from war only to feel conflicted by her commanding officer's last words: "I love you." Starting a story off with a simple premise honestly means it can only go up from there. It also keeps the stakes small and personal, so it feels all the more satisfying to watch our hero go through her journey. It also makes the journey feel more personal to the viewer. Everybody has their own definition of I love you. It's a personal statement that's hard to describe because it means that much. Watching somebody who is almost completely emotionless try to find meaning in the most emotional statement somebody can say is really heartwarming. Something I mentioned earlier was the formatting of the episodes. The fact the show tells a separate story in each episode that all connect and contribute to the end goal was honestly a good decision. I feel that if the show tried to go with a complete series format, it would've felt like the story was just being dragged around until the end.


Art: 10/10

This is literally one of the most beautiful shows I've seen. The set pieces are honestly really great and splendid to look at. There was a lot of care that went into creating them. The animation is also very fluid and conveys the mood and tone of what is happening on screen perfectly. There's not all that much to complain about except one or two instances of CGI which is integrated so well it's kind of hard to see unless you're looking for it. 


Sound: 9/10

Sound design is great. Apart from a few pieces that sound out of place or just a few bad reads, it's not too shabby. The music does a good job of conveying the tone of the scene. Couple that with the art, and you'll be in tears. A lot of the music is fairly mellow which I really liked since the show tends to be more toned down and grounded. The VA's brought their A-Game and just put so much emotion into their voices. It made the characters feel human and not like they were just reading their lines for a paycheck. I feel it would've been easy for them to overact rather than underact, but they skillfully were able to keep a hold on how much emotion they put into their performances and knew when to reel it back.


Character: 9/10

The characters were done well. Everyone gets a moment o shine and is developed properly so that they aren't just walking tropes. Aside from a small issue of some of the main characters showing up and never really reappearing until later down the line, it handles most of them fairly well. They all contribute to the greater story arc by having their own personal arcs and issues they need to work out as well. I feel they could have been easily rushed, but the episodes they are featured in and take their time in setting up how they feel and why they're having such a hard time at this point in their life. It's rare to see characters nowadays actually sit down and say how they feel or what's going on in their head. By actually sitting down and just letting them talk and work things out, it makes them a lot more human than never bringing up their issues at all. 


Enjoyment: 10/10

I loved it. I don't think I can describe how much I loved it. This series made me cry multiple times because I cared about Violet and her struggles or what the other characters were feeling at that moment in time. This show made me feel something other than being angry that I didn't feel anything. It told the story it wanted to tell, and it didn't let itself drag. That's good storytelling. 


Overall: 10/10

I don't give away 10's. I give 10's to shows that have earned them. Violet Evergarden bleeds that kind of passion. It has a great story, amazing characters, and beautiful art and voice acting. It's a show worthy of your time. It doesn't bait you into needing to watch a sequel. It's a satisfying story of finding the meaning of "I love you." I would highly recommend it to anybody who enjoys grounded storytelling or just anybody at all.

Violet Evergarden (the series) is unlike any anime I've watched so far in that it aspires to be something other than entertainment. Rather than being pulp entertainment aimed at teenagers, it aspires to be Art. It aspires to be high literature. And as such it has to be judged by a different standard than you would apply to a Gintama or a Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid. 
The series is nothing less than an artistic examination of what it means to be human. Sometimes it succeeds. Sometimes the series is a bit ham-handed in its attempts. It is an attempt worth watching. It is one ofabout four series that I go out of my way to catch every episode.


It conducts its examination through the eyes of the title character. Part of the confusion comes from the nature of Violet (the character) who is somewhere on the cyborg to full robot scale. She may be mostly human with a set of sophisticated prosthetic arms or she may be a robot. That she is relatively emotionless indicates she is further toward the fully robotic end of the scale. The technology that the character embodies is well wildly ahead with the mid 1800's - early 1900's Europe in which the story happens so it is possible that the character isn't even from the story's place and time. But that is irrelevant. What does matter is that Violet (the character) doesn't understand what it means to be human at all.  


The fictional character that most reminds me of Violet, is Data from Star Trek the Next Generation. Data and Violet both want to be human. Neither fully understands what that means. And the audience gets to explore what it means through the experiences of these two innocents.


This is not to say that it isn't entertaining. The humor stems from the ineptness of the character and the slightly warped view of society. There is enough eye-candy for anyone interested in that.


Where will it all go? Will Violet fall in love as she comes to better understand what it means? Will we see more of what she actually is and where she comes from? I look forward to finding out.

After being discharged at the end of a war, our titular Violet takes a job as an Automatic Memory Doll (basically a ghostwriter) and starts writing letters for other people. So far so good but what's the show actually about?
It's an anime where the focus is on the characters, specifically on Violet who, after leaving behind the harsh military life, needs to learn how to live and interact as a civilian. 
It doesn't rush anything, it takes it sweet, sweet time showing Violet's growth as a person and her interactions with the people around her. It can be best described as a "slow burner".
Violet asa character seems to be a base breaker for the viewers. Her emotionless, robotic responses have been off-putting for a large number of people. If her character were to stay the same through the series, I'd agree with this view but since the show is all about her growth and evolution, I don't mind. I actually find her and the way she misconstrues what other people are saying quite endearing.\n
It's also a great exercise in world building. The world of Violet Evergarden feels like a real, breathing world full of cities, trains and landscapes.\n
And it's also about the small things in life. About personal dramas and emotional dilemmas. \n
The art is so high quality, it might have required the budget of a small country to animate. Regardless of one's opinion of the anime, there seems to be an unanimous consensus that it looks great.\n
The sound is doing it's job and goes well with the general atmosphere. \n\n
Is this anime for you? \n
If you've come here after reading the light novels and expect to see a faithful adaption, then no. I don't really mind this, I think that, most of the time, the source material is irrelevant when it comes to an adaption. The anime should be able to stand on its own and that it does.\n
If you have very high expectations for this show then you might be severely disappointed. I came with zero expectations and so far it's my favorite anime of the season.\n
If you have a short attention span, don't really like character driven shows and prefer a fast paced plot, then it's probably not for you.\n
But if you do enjoys slow paced emotional roller coasters sprinkled with slice-of-life elements here and there, then give it a try.

As far as I can tell from the first 4 episodes, 'Violet Evergarden' is definitely not for viewers looking for a fast-paced show surrounding action. It seems to be a slower-paced drama surrounding the build-up of characters. To me this show is very enjoyable so far, especially due to the amazing art and soundtrack. 
I was only made aware of this show a couple of months ago (I also haven't read the source material), however apparently this show has been hyped for a very long time. Obviously as of now many people seem to either claim this show is a masterpiece or think it's overratedgarbage. The issues a lot of people seem to be having with the show is the slow plot and Violet Evergarden's character. 


The fact that the main character is seemingly very bland and socially inept means that her character is going to grow over the course of the show. It almost seems unfair to me how her character can be criticised so heavily so early on in a series that is clearly using her character development as its main story. Likewise, saying that her character is amazing so far is equally unjustified but to me I have hope in her character improving as the show goes on. 


I completely understand if people are saying this show is overrated. However, saying this show is overrated as your main/only point of criticism to justify that the show is awful then I find that ridiculous. How popular a show is shouldn't take away from your own experience while watching it. I do understand if people are disappointed due to the anticipation of the series as the style and pacing of the episodes so far are probably not what some people expected. 


The visuals and music are simply amazing and manage to hold your attention despite the lack of action. I really enjoy the slower-paced narrative style as well as the character build-up. However if this type of anime isn't for you then I doubt you will enjoy it.

I only bother to write reviews for truly transcendent animes, so it is no surprise this anime is getting its own review.
Violet Evergarden might seem like a slow burn to some, but that is the point. To me, I was hooked from the beginning, but I prefer animes that build up than those that reach their peak at the beginning or middle of the season.
This anime is all about one question: What does it mean to love someone or be loved by someone? Thankfully, I followed Violet on her journey as she navigates her way to aim at finding the meaning of what Gilbert toldher in his seemingly last moments. This anime is a character-driven one...meaning it is the characters who drive the story, not the other way around.


We meet some genuinely nuanced and realistic characters on the way as Violet goes around writing messages people just cannot say out loud or don't know how to express in words. This anime is not just about love, though, as it tackles loss, giving me some of the saddest moments I have experienced since Dear Nina Tucker was merged with her dog into a chimera. Each character she meets is fleshed out in the short amount of time she meets them, which is no easy task, and each of them deals with grief and love in their own realistic and unique way.


The music and art style are some of the best you will see in any anime, with the soundtrack fitting right in with the unique setting for an anime. It is clear Netflix spent a whole lot on the animation, environmental architecture, facial nuances and overall rendering and style of the show. It is, I daresay, the best-looking anime I have seen along with Attack on Titan (AOT is this high because of the battles).


All in all, I was left floored and enthralled by the first season of Violet Evergarden and cannot wait for the next one.


Violet Evergarden is a unique Slice of Life anime that avoids all the tropes associated with the genre. It is a shining light on the texture of love, and how loss infects one's grief, while also remaining unique, inventive and honest.

This series blew me away. This is how episodic episodes are done right. By the end of the anime, our robotic soldier of an MC could finally become a normal human being.
Even though there weren't many episodes, they both individually and together pact a lot of depth and weren't wasted filler and even though it was an episodic series the transition between them was flawless, I would forget that I'm not watching a series with giant arcs because those half-hour episodes flowed so smoothly together that each individual episode felt like its own mini-arc in the series.    
What makes the story moreinteresting is that the focus of the episode isn't Violet but whatever letter or task she has to accomplish for someone else whose life ends up impacting Violets and she ends up gaining new knowledge and understanding about herself and her relationship with the Major. 


Each character plays an important role in her life and helps to progress the story itself and Violet's character development. 


This is a very character driven show and those tend to be my favorite but it certainly doesn't lack action, on the contrary, our MC is a former child soldier and the story takes place both within the memories of the past war and the continued ability to maintain peace with the two former enemy nations. Doesn't help that some rebels want to maintain the conflict and our little MC gets dragged in the middle of it so we get to see her kick some major butt.


It's also a love story if you can believe it, just a lot more painful, and lacking in the cliches of most romance series that gets overplayed.

Violet Evergarden has its imperfections, but proves yet again beyond the shadow of a doubt that when Kyoto Animation brings the pain, it brings the P-A-I-N.  
Minor spoilers follow, though nothing particularly explicit.
Violet Evergarden's major drawbacks are twofold, but both avenues of criticism lead to the same conclusion: the show does not have firm enough belief in the ability of its titular character to carry the narrative.  First, the show dwells on combat too heavily for its own good.  I don't begrudge wholesale the inclusion of flashbacks to the war; establishing Violet's traumatic background cannot be so convincingly completed without glimpses intothe violent world she first entered, and some of the show's most moving - and visceral - moments come from Violet's final minutes with Major Gilbert.  Every image of Violet's mechanical arms carries so much more weight with the knowledge of how she earned them, and the small looks of surprise on other characters' faces on first noticing her prosthetic limbs offer in each instance yet one more twinge of painful recollection.  The true strength of the show, however, lies in the aftermath, in Violet's postwar resurrection.  The most relevant plot elements and the strongest emotional resonance emerge in the story of Violet's career as an Auto Memory Doll, in the letters she writes, in the people she helps.  Taking time away from that powerful and compelling journey only hurts the show in the long run, and throwing so much weight behind story arcs centered directly on the war - especially in the show's final episodes - robs Violet of the chance to construct the show's true apex herself.  Violet's personal trials and agonizing growth become subordinate to dime-a-dozen shoot-'em-up sequences on battlefields that hold little significance to the audience.


Combined with a handful of puzzling logistical questions and the fact that episodes 9 and 10 provided a perfect ending for the show that the subsequent episodes never approached, let alone surpassed, the insistence on dragging along the dead weight of martial subplots frustrates the show's otherwise fragile demeanor.  Watching Violet handily dispatch enemy troops like the killing machine that she is has its novelty, but why should victory come from the barrel of a gun rather than the heroine's own heart?


A small part of me further interjects that war was not meant to be this gorgeous, and that might have presented some disconcerting dissonance had the show involved wider depictions of battle.  Thankfully, what combat there is remains at a relatively small scale, and, however odd it may be, the animation is as breathtaking as ever.


Second, certain peripheral characters continuously threaten to take away from Violet the screen time and opportunities to demonstrate growth that she has earned.  Her fellow Dolls and her various customers factor heavily into her maturation, and without such emotionally charged interactions, it is doubtful that Violet could ever realize her true potential.  Anime-original characters like Iris and Erica prove that even expanding the cast can work exceptionally to the show’s benefit, if only implemented tastefully – but by the end of the show, Hodgins, Dietfried, and even Major Gilbert himself feel overbearing.  In taking over for Gilbert, Hodgins has assumed the role of authority figure and parental guide in Violet's life, and, stunted as she is, Violet experiences difficulty weaning herself off this manner of ever-present director, which necessitates Hodgins's presence early on.  Violet does grow over the course of the show, however; she proves herself capable of making her own decisions, learning her own lessons, and living a life free from orders.  As she develops, Hodgins should become less indispensable and less present, or at least more of a side character than the authority figure he was introduced as.  Yet, by the series' end, Violet still looks to Hodgins for affirmation and justification.  He becomes almost an unwelcome presence because of his tendency to control any scene in which he and Violet are together.  Dietfried, meanwhile, provides a handful of opportunities for the show to examine Violet's new life in a different light.  As the man responsible for finding Violet in the antecedent action, a malicious reflection of Violet's protector, and a lone voice resentful of Violet's struggles to move on, Dietfried complicates Violet's journey in important ways.  On the other hand, he is an unaccountably grotesque character and his insistence that Violet has no humanity seems bullheaded and baseless from the beginning, even more so at the end; in a most ungracious and unflattering turn, the show's final arc attempts to foist Dietfried's emotional baggage onto Violet's catharsis.  


Gilbert, for his part, is the crux of Violet's search for answers and plays such an enormous role in her development that his semi-constant presence might be unavoidable.  The show could not conclude without Violet addressing her feelings for Gilbert in earnest and I find it hard to imagine this series without Gilbert playing such a major part.  Unfortunately, the tragic and moving relationship between these two figures cannot seem to sustain the same poignancy throughout the full course of the series.  By the end of the series, Violet has become a very strong character.  As she grows, she becomes more unrecognizable as the helpless child who relied on Gilbert for everything in life, and while this growth is a great achievement of the series and very much the whole point, it has the unintended consequence of suggesting that Violet is now better off without Gilbert - or, put in a gentler light, Violet is no longer an abject shell without him, having outgrown the need for his constant protection.  If Gilbert were to return to the world as it is in episode 13, how different would his relationship with Violet be?  Some flashbacks do a great deal to contextualize anew Violet's evolving worldview; others circumscribe a sorry suggestion that there is little to Gilbert's personality beyond the fact that he is nice to Violet and highlight an unflattering contrast as Violet's happiness becomes less contingent on Gilbert's approval and increasingly the result of her own developing strength.


The show could avoid turning one of its key figures into a shadow hanging over the heroine by shifting the focus of its later episodes.  The flashbacks should have been more limited in scope; Dietfried's role should have been downplayed; once again, the character of Violet-as-soldier should have been removed from the field.  The more Gilbert reappears to deliver exposition of Violet's former self and remind us of how basically nonfunctional she used to be, the less time the present Violet has to demonstrate her growth.  By the end of the show, flashbacks to Gilbert do not feel like chances for Violet to overcome her trauma and learn more about herself so much as pure flashbacks to a state of being that is no longer compatible with the present direction of the show and the characters.


If I could identify a third serious flaw in this show, it would be the writing.  Exhibit A: "Just exploit this orphaned girl as much as you can and dump her in the battlefield when she's no longer of use."  I hope never to encounter such a piece of dialogue outside a comedy ever again.  The writing in this show is usually tepid, dull, and witless - at least boring when it manages not to be obtuse.  Metaphors extend well beyond their expiration dates.  Philosophical orations ring hollow.  Observations that need not be vocalized are, and plainly.  The all-important letters typically fare much better than day-to-day conversation between characters, though even the letters suggest that perhaps an Auto Memory Doll ought to have been hired to script (or perhaps translate) this series.


In spite of the myriad cracks in the cinematic latticework of Violet Evergarden, I cannot bring myself to feel any of these words I say against it.  Truthfully, the dialogue bears little weight on the flow of the narrative for me; the story entire is told through Violet's face.  This is a tale based on feelings, not on words, and, just as Violet conveys her clients' feelings while struggling to mold her language to her needs, this show's true feelings reached me even without the aid of luminary screenwriting.  The details of Violet's origin might as well remain shrouded in mystery, as far as I am concerned; with so much of the show riding on her evolution after the war, how she entered the war in the first place is only a curiosity and not particularly consequential to the overall narrative.  I do not need to know her childhood any more than I need to know about Revy or Major Kusanagi or the Gunslinger Girl troupe, beyond the few scraps of back story scattered across the years.  However much Gilbert may intrude on the present narrative, however much excessive flashbacks may block Violet's spotlight, the confused and intense feelings that Violet has for him override any meta considerations of complex symbolic interaction.  Every shot of Violet's brooch lights up my heart the way the gemstone lights up the screen; every time she grasps for it, I picture the hazy, softly lit marketplace where Violet first discovered how to verbalize her feelings and where much of the show's store of pathos had its origin.  I could pick and criticize and probably warp Gilbert into a negative influence by the end of an essay, and Hodgins for that matter, but all I want is for Violet to find peace and closure and to be able to reciprocate his love, even though I know this cannot be.  All I care about is Hodgins's happiness with Cattelya and the success of his business.  All I care about is Iris making a name for herself, Erica gaining confidence in her ability to communicate, and Benedict learning how to wear real shoes.  Thematic analysis be damned.


Certainly, the elements of war may feel ham-fisted and too pervasive for the show's own good, but these few detours account for so little of the show's true spirit and can never overpower the simple, sweet narratives of Violet helping her clients find themselves.  Every customer has a story to tell through Violet, and each touches on some new element of the human soul that teaches Violet about what it means to live at the same time as it reminds the audience of these things.  The sheer weight of every letter Violet constructs almost defies logic, and yet each is more poignant than the last; every new episode leaves an indelible mark on the show (and left one on me as well).  Hearts bared, tensions rising, souls overflowing with incalculable emotion: Violet's journey is one to the center of humanity.


The finer points of film-making and the technical terminology that accompanies them are somewhat mysterious to me, but Violet Evergarden has the clarity, detail, and boundless quality of art reserved for (well-budgeted) feature films rather than television series.  Violet Evergarden takes "every frame a screensaver" to heart, from the jaw-dropping backdrops to Violet's delicate and stirring facial expressions.  Many character designs reflect the premature age and distress of war veterans; even those for "regular" or unremarkable characters pop so vividly with the peculiar spark that Kyoto Animation adds to every project.  Scenes with dozens upon dozens of characters teem with just as many unique designs; no two Dolls, no two market patrons, no two soldiers are alike.  Violet herself has a positively elegant design, one that encapsulates at first her lethality, coldness, and hollowness, later her naivete, confusion, and turmoil, and eventually her maturity, compassion, and depth.  Her striking features, noble Prussian blue jacket, and shimmering mechanical arms make a powerful impression just through a still frame, before taking but a single step into a story arc.  Even for Kyoto Animation, a studio built on attractive character designs, lovingly crafted settings, and fluid, high-quality animation, Violet Evergarden is an extraordinary triumph.  I cannot remember the last show I watched that was so absolutely gorgeous.


Behind such exquisite designs is a cadre of voice talents more than capable of bringing these characters to life.  Aya Endou, Haruka Tomatsu, and the lamentably little-used Minori Chihara stand out in particular, but the true star - as it should be - is Violet herself, Yui Ishikawa.  Ishikawa's performance evolves with Violet herself, exercising restraint and holding forth as necessary to achieve the greatest dramatic effect.  Violet is similar in temperament to Ishikawa's most famous role, Mikasa Ackerman in Attack on Titan, but Violet is such a layered and complex character that Ishikawa has room to move, test herself, and deliver truly heartfelt lines.  Having heard Ishikawa as Violet, I could picture no one else matching this character so perfectly.  The music complements the tone and appearance of the show with equal aplomb, at times fluttering and sunny, at others reticent and humble, at others curious and complex.  Strings and piano melt across these breathtaking tableaux as if conducted by the scenery itself.  The true centerpiece, the star on the tree, the kiss at the end of the rainbow, is the ending theme, "Michishirube," sung by Minori Chihara.  The Disappearance of Haruhi Suzumiya taught me that there is little in this world more transcendent than Minori Chihara singing a beautiful melody unaccompanied.  Adding piano does not dampen the effect, but adds one more facet to this supremely sweet voice and melody.  I could have this song played at my funeral.


In the midst of everything that Violet Evergarden did for me, what can I say to its detriment that does not sound disingenuous?  The moment never came when I was able to take my eyes off it, so transfixed was I by its every little intricate detail.  A letter never emerged from Violet's travels that did not move me at the deepest foundations.  I believe that every time Violet shed tears I did, too.


Knowing full well that Violet Evergarden is a less perfect show than I would like it to be, I probably cannot justify rating it a 9/10, and once sufficient time has passed, I may decide to lower my rating, but what I felt while watching this show transcends what I thought about it afterwards.

"In general, Age is not a barrier to love" - Violet the lolicon
Ok so, when I was writing the review for violet evergarden while browsing through the review section for references, I soon to realize what people were missing out on, especially preliminary reviewers which seemingly get my nerves on for getting more upvotes on something that unfinished.
So here's my take on Violet Evergarden, a quiet bloomer.
Now I know, Violet is a very boring character that we've seen mostly before. A monotonous, emotionless husk of a borderline robot. Pair it up with essentially an anime about poetry and emotions and yeah, you'll probably sleep throughthe first episode. I know, I did too. I kind of get the complains of why people didn't enjoy the first 3 episodes but frankly after watching the series, I kind of get where Kyoani was trying to achieve here.


The slow and really boring start gave room for Kyoani to slot in minute details and really a lot of guesswork that requires just constant attention. It's an anime that demands you to stay glued throughout. Staying glued allows you to really enjoy the subtle details such as Gilbert saying "I love you" in a manner that every girl would start nose bleeding, or her inability to adapt to an ever so laid back environment which draws in confusion and loss, basically it further enforces on something that was once just glanced off.


Speaking of detail, have I told you about how lovely the art looks? Even if you don't dig into the minute story details, the art would have at least perfectly portrayed the scene of a WW1 era. Colors are simply lush and vibrant and character detailing is just off the charts. It's a work of art.


Coming back, Violet is all (wo)man up, ready to write letters to everyone. This was the part I felt escalated too quickly. It was only an episode ago where she managed to just barely learn to write and next thing you know, she's writing for the princess to restore peace for both nations. But noting that aside, with your eyes still glued, you can really start to see Violet's feelings open up a bit, offering to now help out the princess out of obligation. You really start to notice that this anime isn't really just about writing but about offering help and comfort. This really laid the foundation down to what the anime really is about. 


Oh right, the music and vocals in this are simply fantastic. Vocals have a slight smoothness which gives for a more relaxing experience and the slight restraint of Violet's anger and denial was fantastic. You also get the sense of the environment from light chatter to birds chirping or whizzing wind. Transitions to music are excellent, just seamlessly moving to classical music which blends in lovely. 


Coming near the end, you soon really see a big change to her. She seems to no longer fight out of orders but for herself now. You can feel such incredible amounts of restraint from her, trying to avoid killing anyone. She seems to now showcase great amount of emotions and the willingness to defend everyone, as if she's standing up for herself rather than for orders.


Looking back, this anime seemed like a story of poetry and literature. But clearly, that wasn't its main purpose. There were tiny changes to an ever so boring character that slowly transform an individual to one from the military to a marshmallow. Every episode seem to show very little change but looking at episode 13 and going back to episode 1, Violet is a changed woman. The ever so slow development without trying to cramp in as many sad scenes is what really made this anime so good. It's the process of change through writing that just makes you cry with joy rather than the amount of sad scenes involved. 


And now, we take a minute on the minutia. 


- Colors have a pleasing vintage tone to it, slightly warm, but has a homey feel to it.


- Wind sounds may be a bit too quiet for a plane flying quickly with no roof.


- Violet's backstory is a bit too tragic, borderline cliche, but I won't blame them.


- Cinematography is good, great angles, panning is smooth on everything but complex scenes.


- The salute in episode 1 is quite controversial for many military eccentrics but for someone like me, it informs me of Violet's background. 


- Luculia was a great character that could be developed on more but lacking in characterization


- Some elements of the comedy side may be a bit overdone to showcase Violet's military side


- Episode 5's storyboard was done by the same guy who did Koe no katachi, so a lot of intimacy.


- "Age is not a barrier to love" really showcases the era's neglect for age differences.


- The anime really does well on portraying children; annoying, childish but courageous


- Fighting scenes are fine, smooth and sharp animations, but movement seems too free for fighting on a train. 


- Violet should stop hacking, seriously


- Side characters are very active in the first few episodes but slowly dwindles away until violet does batshit crazy stuff


- Gilbert is cool, very cool.


- Violet seems to only wear one dress for that 13 episode


- Side characters are shit at comforting Violet. Like seriously, a letter. No hug, no words?


- Diethard is a living reminder of Violet's past. Really hateful but important for the story.


- They made recruiting child soldiers seem normal by neglecting Violet's age but somehow Violet is the only child soldier, strange.


And well thus I conclude the review of Violet Evergarden, hope you enjoyed it. Leave a like if you enjoyed it.

This anime centers around the concepts of self-discovery and the accumulation of experiences and human emotions. + this show has a unique and clever way of delivering drama and emotions to the viewers. It does it through letters. The feeling of manually crafting and receiving letters is magical. This is somehow diluted today because everyone wants it done and sent quickly. 
+ each individual sub-story is a gem and eachcontributes to the character development of the main protagonist. Violet’s interactions with each client helped her slowly mature by her learning to express the emotions that she has never expressed before through her clients’ first hand stories. \n
+ the show knows where it should focus on. Even though Violet was not always there for 100% of the time, it all builds up to her development. \n
+ the general plot has a nice build-up and it climaxed and ended beautifully. At the end of the day, we are all rooting for Violet and her future endeavors. \n
+ the dialogue is rich in content and poetically written. The words used were carefully chosen especially during the narratives when the letters are read. Each word on the letters conveys a magnitude of emotions. \n
+ the output of the voice acting is also fitting. The dialogue is given life through the voices and the emotions that were attached with each word. I personally love the rather quiet and clear voice of Violet. Her voice actor did a good job portraying her.\n

The color palette of the frames perfectly complements the emotions/aura of the scenes.\n
+ beautiful character design that is refined to the last detail.\n
+ the animation is crisp and flawless. This is probably the most well-animated drama anime I’ve ever watched. \n
+ I also like the play and meaning behind Violet’s name\n
+ the music is emotionally stirring which complements the scenes. \n

Wrapping this up, what I personally got from Violet Evergarden and what resonates with me are that:\n
1. Letting go of people we love is never easy;\n
2. Learning what love means and healing after letting go is part of the process in finding our own selves; and \n
3. Remembering to live life to the fullest and keeping on moving forward, as well as cherishing the moments we have with the people we love are what will give us a positive and healthy outlook in life.

There is this strange connection that the physical world of humans have on our emotional level. The closeness between feelings and the heart. We are not dolls because most of us have this linkage that places importance in the world we live in. Violet Evergarden is the unlocking of the emotions in our heart, and it left several powerful yet simple messages behind that we all can take in.
One might consider this mature story to be too empty and lackluster as an entertaining anime. After all, it followed Violet. A bland girl who was broughtup by war, lived around war, and still with a mind in the state of war. She truly doesn't know what emotions are, left wondering what the words of love from her dying major meant after surviving the war. So when she decided to become a Doll, a job that took her to a world of emotions and feelings expressed in the form of writing letters for many clients, that was when her slow-paced progression came to light. The thing about the story was that you don't have to relate with Violet. Her backstory with her major explained the situation on why she was what she was, a human comparable to that of a doll. Many of us lived in a time of peace knowing the potential of emotions, something contrary with how she grew up. Her quest in discovering the things that are familiar and close to others was the reason why I'm interested in how she grew with meeting people who have circumstances. Again, it may seem normal to us, predictable per se in how the episodes will unfold, but it's not normal to her and that was why I was intrigued with her interactions with people, gradually molding out her character. She delved into their feelings, a paramount significance towards transforming the unchanging Violet into a woman who will understand the underlying personalities that every ordinary human possesses. There may be little focus for other characters, but the title of this anime placed utmost importance to Violet Evergarden, and this was why I felt the story made sense as it was her story. The rest served pretty well in creating situations to open Violet's mind into the world, and a couple of them did developed given their screentime. The only thing that put me off at times were the melodrama in the earlier episodes along with comedies that felt a bit off.\n\n
Using an obscure setting that depicted United Kingdom about two centuries ago, you will see typewriters, early automobiles, and fashions from the era back then. The different set of architectures were all refreshingly pleasing to see. Together with the character designs and expressions, they were shaded with realistic use of indirect lighting that just amazed me with how each scenes were beautifully portrayed. Definitely stunning and wondrous. There were two main tones used to depict the visuals. Vibrancy, especially in the eyes, contrasted with the monotic stance of Violet but at the same time, it also brightened up the setting. On the other spectrum would be the dullness that elicited emptiness, but it too served to maintain the Victorian setting as there were no bright technologies back then. This, along with subtle visual symbolisms such as the flight of a white dove to represent new beginnings and peace, were important in delivering more depth to a story that might had felt too dry without the attractive art to wash over it. Animation of everything were down-to-earth, reinforcing the realism that this anime had set up. There was no overexaggeration but the careful animation to create the details were enough to fixate my eyes on the screen. I can't find any fault in the aesthetics, it was just that immersive to see. As for the sound, there were moments where the European-style soundtracks stood out. Overall though, their unique quiteness was just there in the background to complement with the scene. It's not too heavy and not too light. Same goes for the voice-acting which was pretty average. The only thing I had in mind about them was that they had a refined dialect feel that reminded me of the mannerism of speakers from the early days.\n\n
Write something and it may just change a person. Violet Evergarden is the story of a girl on her way to discovering what it's like to feel and have emotions. It may be too dull at first, but the simple story of writing for people and gaining new feelings from people is definitely an experience worth giving a try, especially with the great visuals that glossed over some of the issues.

"There are two sides to words" - Cattleya
Showing emotion and feelings in words let alone how LA tries to portray it in a review is no easy feat which may also lead to misunderstandings or lost in translation such is the case for Violet Evergarden...the character, not the anime.
Violet Evergarden is a placid show, but an anime with depths in it's language of words and Violet Evergarden perfectly understands the misgivings, discourse and love of the written language and what it tries to convey to us.
Kyoto Animation ALWAYS had a way of showing emotion instead of telling us, Hibike Euphonium did it, Hyouka didit and Violet Evergarden is no different and this bleeds into the gorgeously done and sleek character designs, backgrounding and they're immense attention to detail to every aspect of every frame.


Violet herself is made out to be a very bland blank slate, however she herself is the focus of the anime (her name is kinda a giveaway) but she at first is an emotionless, anti-social blank slate with no human emotions, but ohhh boy when we know her backstory with Gilbert and his last words of "I love you" bringing out Violet's goal and into becoming an automaton doll is soo heavy on both the audience as well as a part of Violet identity. She does by all intents grow from a husk of blank slate into someone who writes letters in order to bring people happiness where before she was nothing but a blood hungry emotionless "weapon" during the war. Yes, Violet's backstory does have some methods of "emotional manipulation" in making Violet's backstory as tragic as possible especially during wartimes in which the anime was set in, but for what it's worth, Violet's backstory though has shades of emotional manipulation and tragedy to push us into liking Violet, the backstory still has levity in the plot and Violet herself and opening herself to the cast as well as the audience more by the end of it.


Now how Violet Evergarden is structured for the most part, the bulk of the anime is episodic look at who Violet is writing letters to, and by all means the plot structure does more in developing the minor characters in the focus of the episode than Violet herself, however LA begs to differ in some cases as some of the clients Violet goes through has shades of what Violet went through and we learn a bit more about Violet...through the minor character's development in the process of things. It might be said that the minor characters push away and brings less screentime to Violet herself, but LA sees that Violet both grows from these experiences and writing letters and once her backstory comes, it goes somewhat full circle by giving her her humanity and that she's not just an emotionless weapon.


However the only cases of minor characters not being in the limelight as much and are "just support" are Erica Brown voiced by Minori Chihara (a co-worker of Violet and an automated doll) and Benedict Blue voiced by Kouki Uchiyama a postman. but LA understands, that it's VIOLET's story not their thus the support makes sense, loosely.


In terms of animation, well this is Kyoto Ani, thus we have pristine and beautiful detail to animation, from character designs to backgrounding and even some of the more brutal wartimes fights shown is shown in bloody detail. Kyoto Ani's facial animation is brought up in showing emotions again, like LA said above and it's just amazing how the detail to animation makes some of the more emotionally tense scenes play out and how characters don't even need to say anything and we can see what they are feeling. Kyoto Animation did it again!


Voice acting, is tricky to say the least, as Yui Ishikawa who voiced Mikasa Ackerman of Attack on Titan fame, well she voices Violet and she keeps a kuudere emotionless cadence for the majority in voicing Violet, makes sense but keeping that cadence while doing more of the dramatic moments is something else really. Yui Ishikawa is kinda the MVP in this voice cast all due to her voicing the main protagonist, but LA will say the entire voice cast, from Aya Endo as Cattleya, to Daisuke Namikawa as Gilbert, Hidenobu Kiuchi as Dietfried and Takehito Koyasu as Claudia Hodgins as well as the rest of the minor cast was excellent in their portrays.


As much as LA praised Violet Evergarden, it's not without it's flaws, as such Violet Evergarden is a slow endeavor of an anime, Violet herself in the beginning is hard to like because of her emotionless state and anti-social behavior and finally the episodic nature of Violet might deter people from the anime, however LA will defend some of these flaws, such as the slow endeavor of the anime is mostly one because of the episodic nature and us getting used to Violet Evergarden through the minor characters she meet and us getting to know Violet through the phases she goes through from emotionless husk to a human with a goal of spreading happiness and getting over her trauma as proof.


To say that Violet Evergarden the anime itself is definitely one of those anime you NEED to wait and see before passing judgment on it is the case with this anime and the overhyped nature of how this anime came to be didn't help with it's detractors. YES, Violet Evergaden was overhyped even before the the Winter 2018 season even started but even for LA, LA didn't really get into the hype train, LA did find flaws in the anime to annoy LA, but that "eureka moment" of Violet's backstory easily rejuvenated and wholesomely developed Violet into a great main protagonist as mundane of job of her as is to writing letters is.


LA won't say that Violet Evergarden was the "best anime of Winter 2018" as both Cardcaptor Sakura Clear Card-hen and Nanatsu no Taizai's 2nd Season are up for debate for LA as LA's best of Winter 2018. But as overhyped Violet Evergarden was, LA did find Violet Evergarden..."competent in what it was portraying, wearing it's emotions on it's sleeves throughout the anime" rather than "the best anime OMG KYOTO ANI" for a response and this coming from someone who wasn't on the Violet Evergarden hype train.


Violet Evergarden is a tragic yet beautiful story of one husk of a person wanting to spread happiness through letters and finding her place in the world in the process where once she was nothing but an emotionless weapon. Violet Evergarden gave people voices and herself one too and for what Kyoto Ani did to hype Violet Evergarden to all hell, Violet Evergarden herself as a character and the things she went through and getting to know her was nonetheless one HELL of an emotional rollercoaster.

Violet Evergarden, aka the most hyped anime of Winter 2018. It has already earned a lot of praise since the release of the 30 sec CM by KyoAni. People are praising how this anime is going to be the next big thing or anime of the year. Lots are hyping it up. Normally I won't like shows that are too hyped, but being a KyoAni fan, I just had to check out the anime to comment my thoughts. And after 8 episodes, what's my opinion on this anime?
I have read quite a few reviews saying that the show is slow and the pacing is verybad. Well, I can't disagree with that. After all, Violet Evergarden is definitely slow paced, or to be exact it's episodic. If you want fast paced actions in this, sorry but I recommend you checking out other series instead.  Also because it's slow paced, I didn't write my review right after episode 4 just aired. 3 episodes ain't enough for a slow paced anime to get to its climax man, they'll need at least 6 episodes. For Violet Evergarden's case where they have 14 episodes, they'll need to get to episode 7 for their climax and well, it did happen. The plot did start progressing in episode 7. So, that concludes my view that people are too fast to place a judgement on an anime. It's like saying Hunter X Hunter is bad because the first few episodes is generic and empty. Writing a good story takes time man. Also let's not forget that this anime is sponsored/simulcasted on Netflix, where it'll have a high chance of getting a 2nd season. So, what's the rush?


Well, now for the characters, I heard tons of people complaining that Violet is very empty and soulless. Well, in fact...she is. It's also stated by the characters in the anime itself that Violet is like a robot, very soulless and can only carry out order given by others. Now, the problem comes, did Violet develop as a character? The answer is yes, in episode 8 you can see that Violet is actually becoming more humane with emotions. So, that also add in to my point that people are too fast to place judgement on an anime. The other characters are decently written. They are definitely not bad characters but they just aren't important to the show itself. Most of the time is focused on Violet's work as a Auto Memories Doll, where she help others and find the meaning of love. 


The music is okay. It definitely did add in to some dramatic scenes, especially the ED theme. It really didn't stand out but it's definitely not bad. The voice acting for this anime is excellent. They added in a lot more to the characters. So, props to the VAs for this anime.


Now to the part where people are constantly praising about in this anime, the artstyle. Yes, it's beautifully drawn. You can see that the artists did actually pun in a lot of effort in their works. It's by far the prettiest art I have ever seen in a TV anime. The animation isn't bad, it's quite average, but mixed in with such a beautifully drawn art, it's hard to notice the flaws in the animation.


Now to conclude my thoughts on this anime, it's a good anime. Definitely not the best, but not as bad as others claim it to be. They definitely haven't seen shows much worse than Violet Evergarden if they can say that this anime is shit. It's well written, well drawn and well animated. You should definitely watch this if you like slow paced romance drama anime.

The comet Halley transpires in the night sky once every 75 years. That means, one who enters the world on that promised day shall see it with his very own eyes alongside his grandchildren, and those grandchildren shall see it again with their own grandchildren. On those lengthy minutes, the faint trails emanating from the comet's tail draws closer to his eyes. A mountain-sized figure, appearing as a mere spec, that embarked on a journey so mindnumbingly great, has finally tainted the dotted heavens through a path billions and billions of miles long. Its tail leaves behind the sprinkle-like glitter that gradually fades into thecosmic dark. Then it strides away, slowly, but surely, its beauty unnoticed by a myriad of lifeforms sheltering under their homes, with their gazes lowered. Does one comprehend the message Halley leaves as it visits the minuscule blue ball we call home? The unheard words vary for each individual, or the words may not be passed on at all, or the words were there, but not understood. 


Violet Evergarden is a sweet tale of that individual who yearns to understand the words she had not understood, and this yearning has led her to an opened gate that reveals a world tainted with innumerable colors she never saw, colors which were once locked within closed hearts, but now spread open like a parasol carried by a wind-spirit through the mere power of words.



STORY : 8/10


Each of us have taste in the sorts of stories we enjoy. I myself adore these types of stories, and I truly think it was told is such a honey-sweet and wonderful way I leave behind a burst of emotions. It centers around a character who desires certain understanding, and the way this character develops this understanding over time is great! 

The story, from the description lines alone, may seem somewhat convoluted and intricate, but in reality it conveys a relatively simple plot. Violet yearns to comprehend the meaning of Love, and as the story progresses she learns the various ways love can be understood. 

Some may find this anime boring, and some find it interesting. Despite the divisiveness, the anime has appealed to me very well and I certainly enjoyed the episodes. To me, when 24 minutes flows faster than it should be, it is a good sign, and the fact that buffering becomes the cause of insanity, it is a divine revelation that states that you are into a particular series.

The series is episodic, so not all the episodes coalesce directly, as some episodes tend to take place in varying setting and time. However, as many folks think, I honestly have no issue towards the pacing. It is true that so far the anime catches up sluggishly to the source material, but verily, I find that each episode is a crucial part of Violet's development, as I can't begin to imagine how the pacing should be according to other people.

This rating may change, as the anime is not complete yet, but I am looking forward to it!

I have been withholding judgement on this for a while, and now, after watching six episodes, I think I have watched enough to write a review. So, here are my thoughts
Story: 7
Upto now, this series' story is rather....confusing. Not in that it's complicated, but rather it's depth. When I watched episode one, I was hoping we would see more of the war and what what Violet went through during it as she finds herself in the letters that she writes. Further episodes revealed that it was aiming to be a plot progression of character development, with little to nothing mentioned of her past. We areshown her progression not gradually, but in bits or pieces every episode. We see her understand a different part of herself in every episode. It is a series that speaks without speaking, and is a rather odd concept in an age where anime is drowned with shows which try too hard to appeal to the impatient nature of it's viewers. The weekly release format works extremely well for this, because this is not a show that you can binge watch. The plot up to this point consists of showing moments where Violet gains a new understanding of herself with each episode, and at a first glance, will come off as bland given that the protagonist doesn't really talk all that much or show much expression.

Dues to the semi-episodic nature of this series, I give the story a 7.


Art: 10

Well. Art. 

I cannot express in words how beautifully animated this series is. It is by far the best animation and art I have ever seen. While there are more intriguing art styles (like that of the Monogatari series), in terms of attention to detail and the absolute vividness, there is nothing that comes even close. It's not an exaggeration to say that this is probably the best two-dimensional animation ever seen in terms of just how detailed each frame is. You can watch the series just to appreciate how beautiful it is without really enjoying the plot.


Sound:8

The opening theme of this anime is quite beautiful, but to me, it doesn't really stand out much. The closing theme really caught my eye because of the classical Japanese meter, and both the opening and closing are beautifully done. The OSTs are once again, very beautiful, but nothing to truly write home about.


Characters: 8

The main problem with the characters of this anime is that much of what happens happens in their minds, and is difficult for us to see onscreen. I haven't read the Light Novels this series is based on, but I can see that this is the type where much is left unsaid. KyoAni have done a beautiful job of it, and have not tried to provide windows into their thoughts unnecessarily, but I feel that this is the type of series whose characters cannot truly be casted completely on screen.


Enjoyment: 8

In my opinion, while beautiful,this is not an anime everyone can watch and appreciate. Violet Evergarden is an extremely well made on technical level anime. Good artstyle, good animation, good sound. It simply is a very pleasant show to watch.
If I had to describe the story, on the other hand, I think I would use the term 'academy award movie' or 'oscar bait'. As in, it feels as though it's made to pander to audience with tastes similar to Oscar's academy awards. You know, the kind of people who absolutely love romantic historical epics, biographical dramas, romantic dramedies, family melodramas and other stuff that wins Oscars.
After the first episode it becomes obvious what one should expect from this show.A story about coping with loss, war ptsds, love, feelings and etc. Typical drama stuff. If you are one of those people who enjoy it, go watch Violet Evergarden, this is your anime of the season. Those who don't can just settle for one episode to decide weather they want to continue.\n
Those reading these my unstructured ramblings might think that I really dislike the story, but the truth is, it's well written, well executed, and so far I enjoyed watching the show, despite absolutely hating dramas. My main and, perhaps, the only issue so far is the predictability of the story.

So far, this anime has really been something special. It doesn't quite merit a full 10 rating (as of yet), but what I've seen so far is excellent and in some ways I suppose I'm being a little conservative in giving it a 9.
The most obvious thing to praise is the breathtaking animation; it has an undeniably cinematic quality, and could very easily pass for the highest quality of Ghibli release. From episode 1 to 4 there is a staggering selection of varied landscapes, from cities to fields devastated by trench-esque warfare and serene, untouched countryside. Each one manages to elicit the same "oooh" ofalmost childish wonder as it bursts onto your screen. 


Second is the emotional heft it carries. Violet is an incredibly touching character to watch, not just because of her own thought-provoking emotional and moral conflicts (the most prevalent of which is her relationship with the still enigmatic Major) but also because of the clarity she sheds on those that she comes to know better in the Auto Memory Doll Staff. However, one thing I might mention is that it often panders towards excessively sentimental. Don't get me wrong, Violet Evergarden is chock full of some really touching and heavy thematic substance, but you often get the sense that the creators are fully aware of this. At times, a little more subtlety could've gone a long way, especially in Eps 3 and 4.


However, this doesn't take away from the overall effect of the show, and at times it can be surprisingly whimsical and light-hearted. Much of the humour derives from Violet's low-key savage blunt honesty, which is consistently funny (though it could get tired if KyoAni continually insist on it). Overall, this is definitely worth a watch. I can't wait for the rest of the series!
