I will admit that there have been times where I’m unable to express how I truly feel. I’m sure everyone has those moments, though; they know that they feel a certain way, yet they can’t put those feelings into words. However, I will try today; I will try as hard as I can to put my feelings for this particular anime into words. After all, I’ve waited so long to watch this anime, from the moment it was announced to the day (after) it was released on Netflix (because I wanted to watch it legally). Even so.... despite the facts being that this anime wasanimated by Kyoto Animation and the light novel it was based off of was the first to win the grand prize in any of their contests, was the wait worth it? Was this anime able to meet the expectations of me and everyone else who eagerly awaited it?


From the looks of it, yes. At the very least, I can speak for myself when I say that Violet Evergarden was worth the wait.


Violet Evergarden follows a girl named.... well, Violet Evergarden, who was raised to be a “weapon” for the military in a war. Gilbert Bougainvillea, a major in the military, did not treat her as a weapon, however; he treated her with kindness and treasured her....right up until he told her he loved her right before the war ended. Having lost her arms in the war, Violet is left with only those words that her beloved major told her and no understanding of what they mean. In order to understand, she ends up getting a job as an Auto Memories Doll, who write letters for people who are unable to do so or have trouble expressing their feelings. From there, Violet’s encounters with her clients not only change their lives for the better, but they also help her grow and understand emotions better.


See, that last sentence alone capitalizes the second best thing about this anime (and I’ll get to the first best thing later), and that is the character development. All of the characters get a great amount of development, from the main characters to the supporting characters and even those who only appear in one episode. Even the characters I initially found annoying for one reason or the other, I ended up sympathizing with them; if an anime can do something like that, it’s doing a good job. In the center, however, is the titular character, Violet Evergarden, who gets the best character development of all. As fascinating as it is to see how she affects the lives of those around her, it’s simply quite amazing to see how it all affects her, as well.


The character development helps the overall story, as well. There were moments where I was admittedly not too invested in what was going on, but those moments were few and far between; for a large majority, there was quite an amount of emotional investment. Take episode 10, for example; given the situation that was going on in that episode, I will just say that by the end, I was in tears. (It’s kind of funny, actually; Violet is starting to understand emotions throughout the course of this anime, and I was starting to get emotional as I watched!) With all of that said, some people may say that each of the stories told in this anime aren’t really connected to each other, but I can confidently say that whoever would say that doesn’t know what they’re talking about. All of them are connected in that we see how Violet grows through all of these experiences; thus, even if these stories aren’t connected, they are.


“Sincerely” by TRUE and “Michishirube” by Minori Chihara, which respectively serve as the opening and ending themes, are truly music to my ears; both are beautifully composed and wonderfully sung, and I could listen to them many times! (In fact, I already have, in the opening theme’s case.) On another music-related note, “Violet Snow” by Aira Yuuki is very beautiful, too; I can remember it being played when one of the first PVs of this anime came out, and it was pleasing to hear it again in the last episode. While I can’t really say much about the Japanese voice acting because I watched the English dub, I can say that the English voice acting was superb, with every voice actor, especially Erika Harlacher as Violet, doing much more than just fitting the roles they were given. The best part about this anime, however, is the animation, and I really mean it when I say this; it is breathtakingly gorgeous, even by Kyoto Animation’s usual standards. The backgrounds, the character designs, the colors, the animation.... It was clear to see that on an artistic scale, this was KyoAni at their finest.


Overall, Violet Evergarden was truly a great anime. Looking for an emotional rollercoaster with gorgeous animation? Watch this one! It’ll probably leave you experiencing pretty powerful emotions.

Heartbreak after heartbreak... Every single episode... That's what "Violet Evergarden" is. 
"Violet Evergarden" is one of those shows that have been hyped up for the longest time ever, but it is also one of the shows that I tend to avoid. "The art is nice, but where is the story?"
Yes, don't expect to find an emphasis on a story in "Violet Evergarden." Instead, expect to see multiple stories throughout the series. You can even skip around episodes or watch the episodes out of order, and you can still understand what is going on. Why? Because "Violet Evergarden" is an anime that is portrayed through a"realistic" lens. Life isn't all about crazy exaggerations and stories. Life is more than just one main character. This anime was more than just "Violet Evergarden." This anime is also about the people in her life. As you watch the anime, you'll almost always be hearing someone ELSE'S story. But through those stories, Violet learns more about herself, which brings us to the main reason that "Violet Evergarden" is a good show.


"Violet Evergarden" is an anime with the strongest character developments ever. A life doesn't need a MAJOR event to change. It can be one small event, such as looking for a job as an "Auto Memory Doll," a female scribe who writes letters for people. That's precisely what Violet did. At first, she wanted to be a doll because she wanted to know what "I love you" meant, but eventually, she wanted to be a doll so that she can slowly change other people's lives, to let people's feelings be expressed, and to bring people together. Every single episode is another heartbreaking story that Violet has to know through her job of working with people to write their letters. Every single episode, you will see Violet slowly change. 


The first episode in the "Violet Evergarden" series is named as "I Love You and Auto Memory Doll," but the last episode is named "Auto Memory Doll and I Love You." Yes, they're the same exact words but rearranged in a different way. To me, this is important because it represents how much Violet has changed over the episodes. The love of her life died. She's just living to find out what his last "order" meant. She's only working as a doll to find out what "I love you" meant. But eventually, "Auto Memory Doll" came in front of "I Love You." Yes, she still cares about the major. She still can't forget her past. But she has changed. She is more than a tool that takes orders now. She is a HUMAN now. She is her own individual, and I think it is very beautiful how she found herself after all these episodes.


So yes. Don't watch "Violet Evergarden" if you expect a big story. DO watch "Violet Evergarden" if you want to see the most beautiful character transformation ever. Here is a warning though: the art is striking, and you will cry. But you'll love it.

Now I have to say, I don't typically watch anime dramas, but I had to give it a chance after hearing so many people raving over this anime, and boy was it worth it! Violet Evergarden follows the story of a former soldier who lost her arms following the climax of a war she seems to have repressed. Seemingly left without a purpose after losing her commander, our titular character, Violet Evergarden, takes on the job of a Auto Memory Doll, a sort of writer-for-hire, in an attempt to better understand human emotions and, more importantly, what it means to love after being confessed toby the aforementioned commander.


As someone also not fond of episodic anime, I have to say that this series really knows how to give the audience a unique story every episode that almost always manages to make us, or at least me, wonder what's going to happen next. While the anime typically follows the episodic theme, there is an underlying plot that really comes to a head in the anime. This is definitely one of those series that'll have you binge-watching the series if you aren't too careful.


The characters for this anime are all unique and almost always manages to make me connect with the characters. I can only think of maybe two instances where I couldn't really connect or sympathize with the minor characters of an episode. Other than those few instances, the characters were very well-written and some even left me wishing to see more of them. As for our main character, Violet is quite the interesting case. She starts off as a character incapable of exhibiting empathy and really understanding the emotions of others. However, as she assumes the role of an Auto Memory Doll and really connect with the customers she is assigned to, she begins to better understand the emotions of others as required for her job. Eventually, when Violet is forced to confront her past and recall previous events leading to her amputation, we witness out protagonist hit her lowest point and really express her vulnerability. Violet is just really one of the most realistic characters I've seen in recent anime and I really appreciate the detail taken in portraying a character like her.


The animation is absolutely gorgeous. While the art style isn't really unique, the backgrounds are really breathtaking and the characters aren't too similar in appearance. What I like the most is the detail given to the metal prosthetics Violet reveals every episode. I know some people aren't fond of the constant attention given to Violet's arms, but I really like the CGI-animation given to her arms as it looks just amazing. The soundtrack is also pretty good. It's not generic, and it always fits the mood of the story at each given moment. It's not too memorable but I remember really liking some of the background themes.


The series ended with a card mentioning future project, but I'm really hoping there won't be another season to this anime as I feel like the series ended perfectly, and I fear it might be ruined with an additional season. Overall, I give this series a (9/10); the reason why I can't give this season a perfect score is because of maybe two episodes I wasn't too interested in. Those episodes were also the ones containing the characters I couldn't really connect with. I won't reveal those episodes because I don't want to sway the opinions of others. However, I will say that this anime is definitely something worth giving a try.

I just finished this piece of telivision and wanted to get some of my feelings down in words. This show isn't perfect, and I actually dropped it four episodes in on my first try, but it was able to get an immense amount of emotion out of me when I decided to give it another go.
The bulk of the enjoyment out of this show comes from how it made me feel. The art is amazing, the sound is good, and direction is great. When put together, they set up perfectly when the show wants to get emotional in a few episodes. I particularly enjoyed episodes7 and 10 for these reasons, and the other episodes from 5-11 are stellar. Everybody involved deserves a round of applause. After each of these episodes, I found myself feeling a lot of emotion, and ended up crying after several of them. I would recommend this to anybody that is even slightly inclined to this sort of thing, - you'd be missing out if you pass it up.


Even though it is worth watching, the show does have it's flaws. First, it feels a bit too episodic. It's not too much of a bad thing, but there's not really a strong overarching story - only Violet's character development. While this enables the series to have some extreme emotional moments, it hindered my engagement (hence why I dropped it my first time through). It also has some very bland and uninteresting characters. Most of the cast besides Violet herself and one episode only characters feel flat. Luckily, the one episode characters are generally amazing and help enable the high levels of emotion that happens. Lastly, the last two episodes are fine, but they definitely aren't as strong as the series middle.


As for subs vs. dubs, I'd personally recommend the dub if you are on the fence, but just go with whatever you prefer. Watching the dub allows you to devote more attention to the amazing art, which is a huge boon of the series, but the sub VA's are also good as well.

Story: This is the story of a girl who is on a journey to find love. She was a killing machine in the war and is not very good at understanding the emotions of people, or even certain words. This is due to the fact she was orphaned as a child. Now that the war is over she is on a journey as Auto-Memory Doll, Violet Evergarden, learning about emotions as she helps people write theirs into letters. When I first started watching it was pretty interestng but I thought it was an weird theme and was going to be another cliched girl learns emotionsanime. It exceeded my expectations, though. It was a heartwarming tale of Violet Evergarden, the young girl from the war. Throughout her journey as an Auto-Memory Doll, she went to many different places to write letters for people, in which we learned about their stories of love as well. This show had me crying the entire time and thinking about what love is to me


Art: The art for this anime was absolutely beautiful. Each scene has so much well-drawn detail that I felt I was in the story. The characters were all beautiful and well-drawn. They were able to show emotion well in the eyes. This show has many scenes showing lovely views of nature and it's clear they intended to do those well. Even people who didn't like the show would have to admit that this is some pretty art.


Character: The main character in this series was Violet Evergarden. Her emotional growth in this series was immense, her turning from an orphan, only trying to survive, to an (almost) emotionless killing machine, who only cared for her commander, to a girl who cries and knows what love is. The other countless characters we meet have deep feelings and unique personalities. It's hard to dislike any character or at least understand their feelings. Assuming there really is a season 2 (which, with that ending there better be), I am hoping to learn more about the other supporting characters.


Overall: I didn't realize while watching this how fantastic of a show it would be. I sped through it in two days, so deeply moved by all the emotions of the characters. I highly recommend it, and truly hope a season 2 is on the way.

I've seen a lot of people complaining about the lack of story or progression in this show, which I think is a damn shame, because at the time of me writing this Violet Evergarden is the only piece of fiction in any medium that has made me legitimately shed tears. I'd like to pretend that this is in any way a fair and balanced review but I'm currently drying my eyes after finishing the tenth of the show's thirteen episodes and I can't in my right mind say I'm not highly emotional right now. That said, as a person who really appreciates good characterization anda well-paced slow-burn story, Violet Evergarden is hiding a deep, touching story of love, maturity, and pain under those stunning visuals and, coming in at only 13 episodes, you'd be remiss to not at least give the show a chance.

“I want to know what I love you means.”
This anime is surprisingly beautiful, and not in the traditional sense, even thought the animation itself is also noteworthy. Moreso, it’s the act of seeing a character grow to become something completely different grow which it started from that makes it amazing. Violet Evergarden will touch your heart in so many ways.
The first thing we should talk about is Violet as a character, who you find very difficult to emphasize with, seeing as how she doesn’t really show much emotion to begin with. But, as she starts interacting and making friends you slowly start to see thiscrack, and eventually, even though she is still very rigid and robot-like, she becomes functional.


The second best thing that the show does is how it presents its story telling. It tells it’s story linearly, but uses Violet interacting with different characters to tell their individual (and often slightly painful or sad) stories, while also tying the main plot together. Eventually, it paints a clear picture of Violet’s progress, and also makes you feel strongly about the episode specific characters, which is suprisingly affective.


The last thing I want to talk about is it’s emotional impact, and oh boy is it rough. This show will clothesline you if you have ever felt abandoned or misunderstood, and it portrays these feeling throughout the show, whether through Violet or most of the characters. I’ll be honest here and say right now, I couldn’t sit through the show in one sitting, and I was in tears for the majority of certain episodes. About halfway through, the show goes into emotional overdrive and I’d recommend taking a break, as the second half is very emotional and should be treated carefully.



So without further ado, we have some negatives, even though they are few and mostly inconsequential. The biggest problem is the suprisingly average soundtrack, which while not really needed here, could use a little work. The other thing is the sometimes lack of clarity for what’s going on, as the show tends to jump around sometimes.



Well that’s about it for this review so I guess: TL;DR: Violet Evergarden is an amazing anime that I would recommend to everyone, which great characters and animation, and a thought provoking and emotional story.

Much like the protagonist of this anime, from whom it gets its name, Violet Evergarden is like a doll: a beautiful exterior with an empty fluff filled center. What Violet Evergarden does so greatly in the animation department is almost completely overshadowed by the dull empty story that sadly amounts to little to no value. Like a doll, you can go on a couple imaginative adventures with it, but once realize it's simply a hollow piece of fabric you move on to more interesting things with your life, as should everyone who reads this review thinking of watching this anime.
Here we are with yet anotheranime to get pumped out by Kyoto Animation with absolutely amazing visual quality and no substance. At this point, I’m not sure if I should expect this continuing forward or should still hope for anime like they made in the past. For a while back there Kyoto Animation only made incredible anime, but currently, at least for me, I've felt an incredible emptiness from all the anime released there from. It's all so very hit-and-miss at this point. That aside, I'm sure you could tell by my opening and that number "5" sitting at the top of my review; I don't really like this anime that much. I went in pretty excited, as I usually am for anime from this studio, because they've got a pretty good track record, at least in the past, of excellence, but Violet Evergarden is anything but excellent.


The story revolves around a street girl who's taken in by a military commander who teaches her to speak and kill people during a civil war era in a fictional Victorian country. She basically becomes some super assassin who only follows orders, but then the war ends and the commander dies and tells her to live on in a regular life, much to her confusion. The main bulk of the anime is this girl, Violet, going around the country with her newly acquired job as what the anime refers to as a "doll", or a glorified ghost writer. Each episode she helps write a letter for some person and it inevitably tries to be sad and emotional in some way. Over many letters Violet learns about the emotions she didn't know she had as well as what "I love you" really means, or so the story claims. 


I felt a massive disconnect with this story. The main protagonist is extremely boring, and robotic. Ironically, it would have been more interesting if the protagonist was a robot trying to understand what love is, because I would have an easier time suspending disbelief and understanding the character's perspective. Then, with that perspective the story could potentially explore love in ways that you wouldn't have normally thought of it and brought new understanding to the character and the viewer at the same time. Instead every episode you just get hit around with a generic sad plot that's trying really hard to be emotional and sometimes Violet will exposit aloud about how she’s sad now too. When I can observe the writing effort to make something sad rather than just getting injected with emotion by my viewing, it really takes me out of the experience and makes the emotion feel forced, as does most of this anime.  Each episode presents a new sad story of someone I have no reason to care about with a sterile doll of a person interacting with them as they tend to end up crying. You would be reasonable to believe I think sad and sappy stories are bad, but feel free to check my anime list here to see that that's wrong. I don't think sad and sappy stories are bad, I think this story is bad. It’s forced, gives no reason to care about characters in each new setting and just doesn’t get to me at all.


The main reason why this anime falls short is the characters. No one in this anime is interesting, most especially Violet. Very few characters get multiple episodes of screen time except the small amount that work at the main work place of Violet, most of which are very basic and uninteresting and in the end serve no purpose. Violet is the pinnacle of this being almost quite literally a living doll. Even a little girl later in the anime thinks she's an actual doll, she's just that boring. This could be fine, because this essentially removes her character from scenarios putting the entire brunt of the quality on the story of the people she's writing for in each episode, making her the same as you, just a viewer. This is ineffective because of two things though. One, the stories of the other characters are mostly uninteresting and uninspiring forced emotional experiences about characters that are difficult to care about. Two, the story keeps trying to go back to Violet's story and past as if it's interesting or important. Pick one, she's either a bystander and the story of everyone else is important and we learn about love through interesting stories, or Violet's growth is important and we learn about Violet. This anime unfortunately splits the baby here. The baby is dead now, but at least it's wearing a pretty dress right?


The visuals, in my opinion, are also really mediocre. As always with Kyoto Animation, the quality is through the roof, but that's really the only good thing I can say about the animation. Quality alone does move mountains for my opinion of art, but it's not getting anything past a 7/10. The visual's purpose is to serve and strengthen the story. The visuals are almost completely irrelevant to the story, the beautifulness of it all really doesn't mean anything, it just is high quality and that's it. The cinematography is basic, simple, which is fine, but I couldn't possibly say that it's anything great with just basic and simple. No interesting visual moments, no use of interesting lighting or perspective, just basic. Once again, this puts the brunt of the show's value into the story and in fact focuses on it, which I once again say is weak. The visuals only further illuminate to me the flaws of the story.


The sound was unobtrusive. I don't remember any of the themes musically, but I don't recall them being bad, which is fine. The voice acting is also fine; no one gave a notably good or bad performance. The opening and the ending theme are both skip worthy; I never listened to them past episode 1. 


Naturally, with all this grief I gave this anime my enjoyment level was very low. How could it be any different? I always hate when I catch myself already analyzing a show while I'm watching it because it's so uninteresting. I want to be enveloped by the story and not really think about whether it's good or bad until after I'm done watching, but I'm torn out of this anime's world so easily due to its boring characters and story. I can’t just sit 13 episodes straight ogling at visual spectacle alone, eventually that novelty wears off and your left with a boring old doll. Do yourself a favor if you haven't seen this anime and just go watch something else, we've long since moved past playing with dolls, or maybe that's just me.

Enjoyment of this anime really comes down to one thing - can you invest and buy into the dramatic content.   The first episode is easier to like than any other (imo) because it has just enough action and conflict to bring in average anime fans.
But after that?  Each episode follows the path of some ass kicking dramatic situation that the main character must resolve the best she can.  The main character, Violet, is lacking in any social skills and understanding of basic emotions.  It is though this journey that she evolves, and this is the emphasis of the complete storyarc.


I fully admit I am an absolute sucker for dramatic content, as long as I like the characters.  This anime absolutely would crush my emotions time and time again.  I could feel it coming at the beginning of each episode, build, and release near the end.  This leads me to believe there is a lot of well placed foreshadowing at the beginning.  And the structure of each episode is built on unleashing powerful emotion before each story concludes.


I love the emphasis on the power of the written word (letters), which is something in real life that most people are getting further and further from.  I used to write meaningful letters.  I used to write meaningful emails - now it's all texts and instant messaging - and the power of a well thought out, written letter is being lost.  It's an absolute shame, and I think a lot of people who have not shared my observations or experiences?  Just don't care.  It's not a problem, because it was never part of life in the first place.  So I get it.  To a lot of viewers, this anime may seem contrived, and pointless - especially if you can't slip into the story, characters and their experiences.


But if you can?  Violet Evergarden isn't just good - it's an instant classic.  My only complaints are nit picks about the world building and technology.  It's all cool, but there is a lack of balance or explanation as to the 1950's style machinery, and the highly complex augmentation which is literally part of the main character.  But does this really matter in the larger picture?  No.  In fact, symbolically all the world building may be in exactly the right place.


Violet Evergarden has absolute top notch production.  10/10 for art and animation as far as I'm concerned.  Everything else is way above average.  My final rating a 9/10.

NOTE: this review is for my own personal use only. i've noticed after a while, i forget why i rated a show highly or poorly, so i'm going to write reviews after completing each series so i can reference them in the future.
rating this show is proving extremely difficult; it has a number of flaws that can't be overlooked and in most circumstances, those flaws would kill the show for me. but violet evergarden excels in all its other aspects that i can't rightly justify what rating i should give it. so i guess i'll list all of the shows faults, then its strengths andsee if i can come to a conclusion




CONS:


perhaps the show's worst fault is its pacing. i personally enjoy slow pacing as it gives time for the audience to get attached to the characters and sympathize with them. when given violet's robotic character, it's especially important to have slow pacing, because too much change too quickly will just feel like the show isn't taking itself seriously. having such a blank slate kind of character, any change at all will seem like a lot, so you really have to pace yourself and avoid having them do a 180. small changes are all you need. and 90% of this show has the kind of pacing i want to see, but they do this weird sort of time-skip-esque sequence. she goes from full robot to full feelings in the span of an episode. in every other episode, violet gains a better understanding of her own feelings bit by bit through her ghostwriting. her character changes microscopically through each ghostwriting, but will have a noticeable effect in the end, after going through so many. but then the show just goes, "yo. she normal now. she can cry." it's way too sudden and almost feels like the show is saying that the ghostwritings are unimportant. 


violet evergarden also fails at a lot of suspension of disbelief moments. i can take the whole "violet is a god of a soldier" thing and that she can outfight anyone you put in front of her, but there are moments when i'm taken out of the experience because i can't believe she can possibly do what she's doing. in the playwriter episode, she jumps across a large lake while "walking" on the water which is completely bullshit. there's no way she could've jumped that far. and the last episode is full of suspension of disbelief moments. parts where the enemy could have easily shot violet, but then just decide to charge in like idiots, especially after seeing her take down 4 guys alone. then there's that one guy who kicks off the bomb. looking at the way those bombs were bolted to the bridge, i'm pretty sure a kick isn't going to dislodge it.





PROS:


this show has perhaps, the best episodes i've ever seen. the episode with the mother writing letters to her daughter was absolutely perfect. taken alone (and you could probably watch this episode alone without any context), the episode excels at everything. the characters, the story telling, the way the episode deliberately hides things from you - all perfect. the episode with the playwright and dying soldier were also wonderful episodes which bring tears to my eyes, which i feel is worth mentioning. if a show can make you cry, then it must be doing something right.


i also love the characters. i really enjoy the clean slate character archetype that violet falls under, but the show also does justice to all of its background characters. with the exception of the big-tittied doll, you get (at the very least) a small glimpse into their characters and what drives them. in this regard, the show makes it feel like a living, breathing world. and every person that violet ghostwrites also feel completely fleshed out. characters who are only there for one episode get so much love. it especially pleases me to see that violet grows with her clients.


i also really appreciate how this show handles post-war lives and how it affects people. it doesn't really say much about PTSD (which would've been nice to see), but it does hit hard on regret for what you did on the battlefield with luculia's brother and especially nails the loss of purpose with violet. although the show kind of cheats with how violet literally loses her purpose (with regards to the major), it does secondarily, or perhaps tertiarily, show the loss of purpose a soldier experience after spending his/her life in a war.


a couple of other minor things, the show's art style was absolutely GORGEOUS. it's perhaps the most visually beautiful anime i've ever seen. the soundtrack was also beautiful and used so brilliantly. because violet doesn't speak much, the music often conveys the feelings she's having, even if she doesn't quite understand them. it's almost as if violet is speaking through the soundtrack.




CONCLUSION:


in the end, i have to acknowledge that violet evergarden is far from perfect, but it excels in so many regards that it's hard to rate lowly. the show is unbelievably beautiful in its visuals, soundtrack and characters, but lacks in its ability to pace its story and violet's character development. i'm giving the show a 9/10, which is higher than i think it deserves, but i know in the future, i'll look back at this show for all the things it did right instead of the things it did wrong.

For those who don’t like reading long reviews, here’s a short one!
Violet Evergarden, to me, was a very enjoyable anime. From the detailed, almost ethereal art style to the characters, story line, soundtrack and beyond. I won’t go into full detail, but let me tell you about the main things I enjoyed and didn’t enjoy as much.
One thing that made Violet Evergarden a great anime to me, is the development of Violet as an individual, discovering her own feelings, those of the people around her and trying to understand the meaning behind them. She grows from an “emotionless war tool” toa fine young lady who doesn’t need orders anymore and decides things for herself.\n\n
Like I mentioned before, the art style and sound track are great too and add a lot to the anime, aiding the emotions to show their true colours.\n\n
Although there are very good elements present, I feel like something is lacking. In my opinion Violet Evergarden didn’t portray its full potential and could’ve been a bit more ‘daring’. But you won’t regret watching this if you enjoy this genre of anime. I don’t cry often during series or movies, but this one did it for me. I’m definitely looking forward to the special episode!\n

ヴァイオレット・エヴァーガーデン - Violet Evergarden`s European premiere in 2017 unveiled an exciting first episode (episodes 2, 3 - released in Japan only) of the upcoming series long before the 2018 release date, and the exclusive sneak peek sparked the desire for more than just a few glimpses into the Slice of Life, Drama and Fantasy anime. The community now waited eagerly for the chance to see the anime as a whole. I'm generally not that easy to impress, but to be honest, the episodes have magically captured me, so this review was almost written by itself. Allow me to share with you some of my impressionsto give you an understanding of the praise and the very good rating for this series. On the other hand, please excuse this relatively long review, which could be simplified and reduced to the following: "This anime, it`s the bee`s knees, it really is".


Story: classical structure, episodically arranged around a central theme (9,5/10)

The first episodes are essentially an introduction that tells us about Violet, the people close to her and, how it came about that she works as an auto-memory doll. We get acquainted with Violet, who was seriously injured in action and on top of that also discharged, since the war is over. The narrative is quite emotional tuned, but well done without exaggeration or even becoming pathetic. Finally, we get to know her main motivation, which runs like a thread through the story.

The adaptation of the story has already been criticized as the chronology differs from the light novel (LN) by Akatsuki, Kana (illustrations by Takase, Akiko) from the year 2014. Although this criticism is not entirely wrong, it does not take into account that one anime and one LN are two very different media. The narrative structure of the LN is a collection of short stories that revolve around how Violet as Auto Memory Doll writes letters for her clients. Each chapter begins with a story that doesn't seem to have anything to do with Violet, but focuses on telling the customer's story. Thus, Violet and her story remain a little mysterious and one is enlightened only by brief flashbacks of her past. This classic narrative style is well chosen for a novel or LN, the reader is drawn deeper and deeper into the story with each page. 

For an anime adaptation of a classic Slice of Life containing drama and fantasy elements, this narrative style was rightly considered less promising. The creative team began with a compact "Coming of Age" style introduction that well illustrated Violet's past.

The content of both narrative modes is the same, only the chronology differs.

If you're wondering whether to start with the light novel or the anime, the following hint may be helpful.

The LN tells many beautiful stories from the beginning and slowly reveals the actual main character and her story. It is exciting and beautiful to read.

The anime, on the other hand, marks the main character's initial status as an emotional infant and then focuses on developing her character through her encounters. In this character-driven plot some very emotional moments are offered.


Characters: successful, sophisticated and demands to take a closer look (9,5/10)

The characterization is successful, but that remains hidden if the series is fleetingly observed or aborted. The individual characters are grounded and very understandable. A small number of only 13 episodes and an extensive cast make a comprehensive description of each character almost impossible. Regardless of the fact that the LN doesn't do this either, both the anime and the LN will convince in terms of characterization. One could argue that the main characters are not sufficiently described. Is that so?


*The description of the characters includes spoilers, so you should first read the LN or watch the anime. *


Hodgins Claudia:

He is a good friend of Gilbert's since the military academy and takes Violet into his care, according to Gilbert's request. Claudia quickly realizes that Violet is not yet socially acceptable and simply needs his help. Since he cannot resist a certain feeling of guilt towards Violet, he decides as founder and owner of the CH postal company to give Violet a job and help her with her first steps in her new life in post-war society.

Claudia is a kind-hearted man, with experience, yet at first unable to tell Violet the truth. 

His background story, as with all characters, isn't explained extensively, but the outline of his being and character is nevertheless well described. In the first episode, his character and behaviour are beautifully portrayed through  the dialogue with Violet on the way back to CH Post's office. Clearly, he tries to make Violet aware of what it will be like if she tries to understand further. But Violet cannot understand it yet, any other explanation would not help and so she must decide for herself what she wants to do.

Baudelaire, Cattleya:

As already with Hodgins, we don't learn much about the background story of Cattleya. The small number of episodes just doesn't leave enough screen time.  Nevertheless, her characteristics are easy to grasp. An educated woman whose beauty is in no way inferior to her temperament. Her abilities as an auto-memory doll are impressive. She has great empathy and can successfully realize the writing wishes of her clients. She is the opposite of Violet, and for this reason she takes over a large part of the care and training of Violet.

Blue, Benedict:

His role was reduced in comparison to the LN. It is clear that a reduction is necessary and that his role is not the most important. I noticed it anyway, because I found the passages in the LN in which he played very amusing. Since his character wasn't completely deleted and the shortening, as I think was done in the right place, I don't consider this to be negative. His character is a little quick-tempered, which stands for a certain insecurity, but he is a good guy under the obviously rough shell.

Cannary, Iris:

Her role is well implemented, and the way she is described resembles the description of Violet's clients are described, later. Basically, she is Violet's first client.  She is actually a good-natured country girl who worked hard to get a foothold in the city. She is not necessarily the most talented and tends sometimes to exaggerate a little, but she knows what she wants and works hard for it.

Bougainvillea, Gilbert:

He is the most important supporting role, but we only get to know him from the retrospective. He treated Violet like a human being and not like a military tool. This becomes clear in the very simple but no less beautiful scene when Gilbert asks for her name and since she does not answer, he gives her a name. Gilbert's desire for Violet to become a person who underlines the simple beauty of the name is only an undertone of the scene, but a very delightful one. His character will further emphasize the background story of Violet in the second half of the series, as will his brother Dietfried, who is the exact opposite of Gilbert and plays this role very well and credibly.

Violet Evergarden:

Her character, as mentioned above, is described as emotionless as well as incapable of understanding or correctly interpreting the emotions of others. Since everyone else shows very emotional behaviour, the impression is of course strengthened. Maybe that's a reason why some people don't want to see the anime completely, which is a pity because Violet Evergarden is a very beautiful anime. The anime begins with the development of Violet from scratch. With every client she writes a letter for, her emotional awareness and understanding grows. As already in the LN, the character of the clients as well as their motives are described very well and Violet's reaction to them indirectly shows her personal development plausibly and beautifully. 


*spoiler alert end *


Visuals: stunning in Art and Animation (10/10)

The series impresses in both art and animation. It comes close to the already rare quality of an anime Movie. The individual character sketches are beautifully drawn and their outward appearances are very different and fit the respective character. The very detailed backgrounds as well as the architecture with strong Victorian style elements have been realized very effectively and with many beautiful details, so that it is a pleasure to watch. The play of light and shadow is impressive and the beautiful colours mix like in an impressionistic painting. The series also features a steampunk element, as evidenced by the simple vehicles to match the era and Violet's technically advanced mechanical arms. The animation is convincing, the movements of the figures appear natural, fluent in the individual movements and result in a beautiful overall picture. I was particularly impressed by the good combination of CGI and hand-drawn material. Besides the two prosthetic arms of Violet, the typewriter from the beginning of the 20th century is also an excellent example for me. Let yourself be enchanted by a European-inspired and breathtaking fantasy world.


Sounds: breathtaking musical arrangements, beautiful OP and good VA & directing (9,5/10)

The background music by California composer Evan Call is great. The individual themes musically describe the characteristics of people and connect the listener with current events. A fine example is the Violet Evergarden theme, which consists of a beautiful women's choir that emphasizes the feminine, the string instruments and the piano convey strength and the desire to discover new things. Have you noticed that a nice typewriter sound and an electric guitar have been included in the arrangement? Splendid music to characterize Violet.

The theme "A simple mission" is a great example of how well the music fits in with current events. The emotionally "awkward" Violet meets the much too hot-headed Benedict, it is obvious that it will be amusing. The instruments of the arrangement interlock as if in an exchange of blows, thus mediating the back and forth between Violet and Benedict. The theme was used to introduce Violet at CH Post Services and is repeated in slight variations whenever there is work to be done.

All in all, I liked the fact that there are hardly any militant pieces of music, though the main theme of the anime is war. So the anime musically focuses on the expression of emotions and thus on the dramaturgy.

The opening of Karasawa Miho (artist name: True) is called "Sincerely" and is one of my absolute favourite pieces of music. Her voice is powerful, clear and yet feminine. The song goes very well with her voice and her intonation is great. Maybe the voice sounds familiar to you, she has also sung the opening "Dream Solister" for the great Anime Hibike! Euphonium. As I said, a wonderful voice and a joy to hear.

The Ending “Michishirube” is a beautiful composition. The lyrics match the anime and although I know that Chihara Minori's voice is very good, unfortunately I don't get along so well with the intonation.

The ending "Believe in ..." was only used for the 9 episode and is a fitting soulful musical ending to the episode. I like the voice of Yuuki Aira better and the musical composition is great.

Regarding the voice actors, I particularly liked Ishikawa Yui as the voice of Violet and Endou Aya in the role of Cattleya. The reason for this is that they both did an impressive job in bringing the character traits of their roles to life and making them audible. In the case of Cattleya a very temperamental and yet feminine charisma. On the other hand, Endou-san as Violet, a very reserved grace in her voice, which only changes into a strong emotional tone in special moments and in a skillful way. 

Among the male voice actors I was very impressed by Kiuchi Hidenobu as Dietfried Bougainvillea. His portrayal of arrogance and malice in Dietfred's voice was very compelling. Even if you do not like the character, you have to admit that it was an impressive achievement.

The dialogue directing is also excellent, the conversations were plausible, but not exaggerated or even boring and predictable. In addition, it was even possible to put one or the other weakness in a better light. Very well done.


I really enjoyed reading the Light Novel as well as watching the anime and I gladly recommend both.



Thanks for reading and have fun watching.

One day I woke up and thought, you know what my life is missing? Weekly uncontrollable weeping. 
The animation is beautiful. The story is fabulous. The character development for Violet is incredibly well done. Through the letters she writes, she grows, and so too does my pile of used kleenex. The ending was incredibly well done. 
I had my doubts when I started this anime because I am usually drawn to very specific genres. Something about the name and the initial imaging drew me in. I don't regret it. Truly though it will wash you in an ocean of feels if you have any semblanceof a heart, so be prepared.

Violet Evergarden is a great example of how an anime can use a repetitive formula for almost every episode, but somehow make it enjoyable and emotional for everyone. It might bore you sometimes because the series can play a little bit too safe sometimes, but that doesn't mean it isn't a great anime that makes you shed a few tears, sometimes.
KyoAni's newest anime adaption of the light novel of the same name, Violet Evergarden is about an auto-memory doll who tries to understand the meaning of "feelings", and know the meaning of words that were said to her in the battlefield of a war shewas part of. It is mostly about how Violet, the anime's main character, tries to become a new person after spending most of her life in the middle of The Great War. Through each episode, she finds out something new about "feelings" by going through situations that involve other people needing help. In the end, Violet Evergarden ends up being an emotional journey, that unfortunately uses a repetitive formula for each episode, even though this doesn't ruin the experience of watching the anime, too much.


From all the aspects of the anime, here's all the scores I give each one of them:


Story - 8


Like I said before, Violet Evergarden uses a repetitive formula, for almost every episode. Most of the episodes are about the protagonist Violet having to help someone who is struggling with something important. Since she doesn't know the meaning of feelings, she faces a few problems until she manages to help this person somehow, and then, learns something new about feelings. The general story doesn't have a focused "antagonist" or something similar to this, so sometime you'll be disappointed that most of the episodes don't lead up to anything. However, even if most of those episodes have the same formula, they still deliver and surprise you in lots of ways. Each situation of each episode is different and that makes every episode unique in their own way. Sometimes, Violet Evergarden catches you off-guard, and ends an episode while you shed a few tears. The ending of the anime is really emotional and interesting as well, so you'll probably won't be disappointed when you finish the series. While the story is truthful to the original light novel, it does takes different routes sometimes, but they ended up being necessary changes.


Art - 10


The visuals and animation of Violet Evergarden are simply outstanding. Everything is colorful, smooth and well designed. I found myself distracted from the episode and just looking at the entire scenario, sometimes. You'll definitely won't be disappointed with the art in Violet Evergarden.


Sound - 9


The entire OST of this anime series is something out of this world. The music is beautifully composed and gets stuck in your head lots of times. Just listen to its Opening Song and its Ending Song, if you think I'm lying. The only problem that I have with this aspect of the anime is that, sometimes, a certain music plays in a certain scene, and ends up not fitting, providing a weird sensation to the viewer. This happened at least three times in the entire anime.


Character - 8


The characters and their development in Violet Evergarden might start "bland", but they'll get better with time. The protagonist Violet, for example, starts as a character in which you can have almost no sympathy so much, but with time, she gets so likeable that it will look like she was never someone so "bland". Unfortunately, a few characters in early episodes are quite boring and never get the good character development they deserve. Fortunately, this stops happening later on. Still, the characters and their development in Violet Evergarden is not bad at all.


Enjoyment - 10


Even with flaws that could be fixed in various ways, Violet Evergarden still provides a great, unique and emotional experience that isn't ruined by its negative points. Personally, I enjoyed the series a lot and shed tears multiple times, and the flaws were almost nothing to me. I'm pretty sure you'll probably feel the same way while watching this anime. 


Overall - 9


In the end, Violet Evergarden becomes another great anime made by KyoAni, and stays truthful to its source material, even if it has to take different routes sometimes. While it does have a few flaws such as the use of a repetitive formula and a character development that starts weak, it still becomes an emotional, beautifully made series, that you should NOT miss out.

Kyoto animation is back at it again with their consistent ability to write a compelling yet tragic story. The phrase "eye candy" would surely be a disservice to this anime's stunning visuals. Couple this with a striking soundtrack and you only scratch the surface to why this anime is a must watch. KyoAni has stuck to their roots here by providing a setting where you will tread in the main character's footsteps. Throughout their emotional journey you can't help discovering pieces of yourself along the way. As a sucker for these types of dramatic anime I will recommend you prepare your tissues in advanced becausejust like so many other tear jerking masterpieces KyoAni has produced in the past, such as Clannad After Story, this will be no exception.


Our journey of course centers around the young women by the name of Violet Evergarden. This military veteran was renown for being a cold-hearted killer. Her collection of blood and scars forced her to not only lose both of her arms but cripple her into an apathetic state. Much like chapters in a book, every episode you will receive a glimpse into Violet's past. The story mainly revolves around her quest of personal development. While heedless of the burns accumulated along the way, her shattered soul seeks the meaning of love. Violet attempts to collect the broken pieces of her past while working as a ghostwriter. Who would have thought the woman with robotic limbs and numb heart could convey the emotions of others so well. While writing these letters she is able to grasp her own emotions and eventually find a sense of closure. The attention to detail and delicate approach to the characters thoughts, emotions, and motives is what caused me to fall in love with this anime.


Leaving all personal KyoAni bias aside my only complaint would be the story. The overall pacing of the anime gives you a feeling that you are missing something important that I can't put my finger on. Yes it invokes an emotional response, but I can't help but feel there so much lost potential. Much like other Light Novel adaptations perhaps 13 episodes was a significant limiting factor. Surely nothing that can't be resolved by simply reading the source material.


Regardless, if you are a fan of KyoAni's cinematic art style and are in the mood for a tale that will surely strum your heart-strings, please don't hesitate to explore this emotional roller coaster named Violet Evergarden.

I'll keep this quick-ish and spoiler free for those who may be considering giving this show a watch. Skip to the end if you just want a quick conclusion.
Story (8)
The story of Violet Evergarden is very good, but not spectacular. It covers a time period nearing the end of war and the struggles that come from it. Violet, originally being a emotionless tool of war, is learning to acclimate to the real world and come to terms with her emotions that she has yet been able to express. While there is one overarching story, each episode seems to be a little story of its ownthat ultimately contributes to Violets character development. The show overall has a slice of life feel to it, and incites a wide range of emotions into its viewers with ease. It seems to start out a bit slow as it sets up the characters and plot, but don't abandon it quite yet as it picks up heavily around episode 7. 


Art (10)


The best part of this anime hands down is the art. This isn't much of a surprise, and is typically what initially peaks everyone's interest in the show. Nothing much to say here other than it's absolutely awe inspiring.


Sound (9)


The sound is great. Voice acting is fine, opening and closing songs are bangers, and the symphonic background music is beautiful and really contributes to the mood of the show. Great stuff.


Character (9)


Initially this category wasn't that great. Violet seemed to be an uninteresting and  typical-for-anime stoic character who simply doesn't understand emotions. But as the show went on, I was completely surprised to see excellent character development, which seems to be lacking in many anime's. I was very happy that there was reasons for why she was the way she was, and that the events throughout the show impacted her. The other characters in the show were very good as well but I won't waste any time expanding on them since the focus is around the MC. 


Enjoyment (8)


I really did enjoy this anime, but I wasn't head over heels for it. I think almost anyone who gets through this whole show would also enjoy it, but it may not be their absolute favorite. Basically, there's no reason not to give it a shot and I doubt anyone would regret watching.


Overall (9)


Overall this is an excellent anime. What seemed only OK at first really had me gripped by episode 7. I doubt anyone would dislike this show, but if for some reason someone does, they can at least enjoy one of the most visually pleasing anime's of all time. I would recommend it to anyone, and while it may not be the favorite of many, it certainly won't let you down.
